Review.Titre: "Free trial" is not really free when credit card information is required
Review.Contenu: The software looked interesting and intuitive but I will not be able to find out if the saved document would be delivered with the proper quality i.e. no compression of images such as logos because pdfFiller requires users to create an account and provide credit card information before being able to download the finished document. "Free trial" is not really free when you have to give credit card information and go back in to cancel your subscription. Whatever rationale companies provide for requiring such information is doubtful at best. I would argue that the real freeloaders are those companies who hope users will forget to cancel their subscription. A recent survey (May 2022) from C+R Research found that 42% of consumers forgot they are still paying for a subscription they no longer use. It is more likely to be the main reason behind that practice rather than to prevent service abuse as there are other ways to authenticate someone without a credit card number. pdfFiller gets two stars for subscribing to this doubtful practice.Edit: To be clear, it is not immediately obvious that you must elect to take the "free" trial which is a small tab amongst many others. The landing page would let you edit your pdf document before any notice about the free trial would appear. You might only realize that you must subscribe to a "free" trial once you spent quite a few minutes editing your document and tried to download it.
Scam/unethical behavior/clickbait. Forces you to create an account to provide a service, and ONLY AFTER specifies that a paid subscription is needed for the service that was offered "for free".
$20/month subscription does not seem worth it for a personal user.

Review.Titre: "Buyer Beware" company... "30-Day Free Trial" is actually a "29-Day Free Trial"
Review.Contenu: Folks, this is a "Buyer Beware" company.... "30-Day Free Trial" is actually a "29-Day Free Trial" ("tricky" business practice) and I don't do business with companies that pull these kind of tricks.  They charged my credit card on the 30th day, early in the morning at 1AM.  I signed up for the "free trial" on August 11th.  August 31st would have been "20 days" and September 10th would have been "30 days."  Instead, I saw that they had charged my card on September 10th (the last day of my "free trial").Had they not pulled this "fast one" (i.e., had they charged my card on the 31st day, instead of on the 30th day of the "free trial")... I may have considered keeping them for the year, because they do provide a decent product.  However, once they pulled this "fast one" on me, I decided not to continue the subscription.Now, the question is... will I actually get my refund (credit to my card)?  Let's see what "nut roll" they put me through for that.  I did receive a confirmation email of the refund, so that's good, but need to go back to confirm in "5 to 7 days."Advice to PDFFiller corporation... don't advertise "Free 30-day Trial" when you end up charging the customer on the 30th day.  That's really what pissed me off and had me cancel my subscription.  It's a poor business practice and makes your corporation look tricky and unprofessional.

The user had to "tell" the computer to switch back to Times New Roman.(2) Another issue I spotted is that if I want to italicize ONE word on a line of text, the entire line will become italicized.  This was cured by deleting the italicized word, then creating a separate text box with the italicized word in it.  The italic text box was dropped into the line of text with the plain text around it.(3) When editing text, the size of text will drop down a size or two.  The writer must "bump" up the text size with the upward arrow to get it to match the text in the original document.Otherwise, I like using PDFfiller.  Of course, PDF editing is not as simple as ordinary word editing.   Or perhaps PDF editing gets easier after continual practice.
